p: Tsetse flies are poikilotherms, and their development and mortality rates are dependent on temperature [ 26– 30]. We aimed to use data on temperature and tsetse abundance at Rekomitjie to test whether observed increases in temperature over recent years are sufficient to explain the observed decline in the local tsetse population since the 1990s. To do this, we used a mechanistic model of tsetse population dynamics that incorporates the effect of temperature on adult and pupal mortality and rates of larval deposition and pupal development, established from laboratory and field studies [ 26– 30]. We fitted the model to a 27-year dataset of Glossina pallidipes numbers caught from bait oxen.
